newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Pertamina to invest $1.3 bln in Pakanbaru block.
newsitem.headline: Pertamina to invest $1.3 bln in Pakanbaru block.

text.p: Indonesian state oil company Pertamina said on Monday that it would plough around $1.3 billion into developing the Coastal Plain Pakanbaru (CPP) block, which it plans to take over from PT Caltex Pacific Indonesia.

"Pertamina will finance by itself the total of around $1.3 billion in investment to develop the CPP block for another 20 years. PT Caltex Pacific Indonesia's contract expires in 2001, Pertamina will continue to develop the block with an enhanced oil recovery project," Pertamina finance director Sugianto told reporters.
"Pertamina views that the government will get more benefit if it is operating the block despite such high investment. We are ready for it," he added.
"You can calculate the benefit, with an average production of around 70,000 barrels-per-day and assuming oil prices at $16.50 a barrel, we will get more than $400 million a year," he said.

"Maybe when the block is handed over to Pertamina in 2001, the production will decline from current levels. But the oil in place will still be there. It is a matter of time and technology to recover the oil," Sugianto said.
"The reserves are still quite big in the CPP block," he added without giving details.
Pertamina said on July 23 it would take over the CPP block in 2001 when the 30-year contract of the operator -- Caltex -- runs out.
Caltex, equally owned by U.S. oil giants Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc, operates four production sharing blocks in Indonesia that produce mainly heavy sweet Minas and Duri crudes.
The CPP block, on Sumatra Island, produces 77,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude oil.
